channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Even in War, Ukrainian Soldiers Find Time for World of Tanks Video Game
item.description: The urge to play a violent video game in the midst of the most brutal land war in Europe since World War II may seem baffling. But it’s a way to cope.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers playing World of Tanks Blitz and other games after training outside the eastern city of Bakhmut in June.

item.title: Paris Makes ‘Summer Terraces’ a Permanent Part of Cafe Culture
item.description: The neighbors may complain about the noise, but outdoor spaces that bloomed under a pandemic program are now a permanent and vibrant fixture of city life.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Place d’Aligre in Paris this month.

item.title: Dueling Tours for Influence as Ukraine War Scrambles Alliances
item.description: As Volodymyr Zelensky went on a diplomatic blitz of Europe, a top Iranian general made his way to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece in Athens on Monday. Mr. Zelensky spoke of a proposal for Greece to train Ukrainians to fly F-16 fighter jets.

item.title: What One Image Shows About the Darién Gap
item.description: A man, his daughter, and the many items left behind.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Zelensky Arrives in Greece, Aiming to Shore Up Support For Ukraine
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky arrived in Athens on Monday, the fourth stop in a European tour aimed at securing more support in the war against Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: Saudi Border Guards Kill Hundreds of African Migrants on Border, Report Says
item.description: A Human Rights Watch report says the guards regularly fire on African migrants trying to enter the kingdom from Yemen and killed hundreds in a 15-month period.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Shuaib Almosawa
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ethiopian migrants boarding a boat in Djibouti to reach Saudi Arabia in 2019.

item.title: Palestinian Man’s Lawyers Say Israeli Police Marked Him With Star of David
item.description: Photos of Arwa Sheikh Ali’s cheek after his arrest showed wounds including triangular marks and lines. The police denied the accusations and said the shapes had been made by an officer’s shoelaces.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A photo released by the Israeli police showing injuries to Arwa Sheikh Ali, a Palestinian who was arrested last week.

item.title: British Columbia Wildfires Leave Dozens of Buildings Burned
item.description: The final tally of the damage will be higher, officials said, although no buildings have been destroyed over the past 24 hours as the fires ease.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Paige Taylor White/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dropping water in West Kelowna, British Columbia, where about 30,000 people have been ordered to evacuate.

item.title: Elections in Ecuador and Guatemala: Four Takeaways
item.description: Outsiders overperformed, underscoring the volatility of Latin American politics. Candidates calling to emulate El Salvador’s crackdown on crime did not do well.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Genevieve Glatsky and Jody García
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Guatemala, the progressive anti-graft crusader Bernardo Arévalo won in a landslide over a former first lady, dealing a blow to the conservative political establishment.

item.title: BRICS Debates Adding New Members
item.description: China wants to expand the five-nation bloc, but the members’ conflicting interests may get in the way.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Lynsey Chutel, Jack Nicas, Alex Travelli and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: BRICS leaders in Brasília in 2019.

item.title: Fake Gold on Private Plane Unfurls Mystery in Zambia and Egypt
item.description: After a plane arrived from Egypt bearing cash, weapons and what looked like gold bars, Zambia arrested 12 people. Egyptian reporters covering the case were briefly detained.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Zambian authorities searched and seized a private jet at the international airport in the capital, Lusaka.

item.title: Luis Rubiales Apologizes for Kissing Jennifer Hermoso After World Cup Win
item.description: “Probably I made a mistake,” Luis Rubiales, the Spanish soccer federation chief, said after grabbing Jennifer Hermoso and planting a kiss full on her mouth, igniting howls of outrage on social media.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, president of the Royal Spanish Football Federation, hugging Jennifer Hermoso after the World Cup final match in Sydney, Australia, on Sunday.

item.title: Nurse Lucy Letby Sentenced to Life in Prison for Killing Newborns
item.description: Ms. Letby was convicted last week of murdering seven babies and trying to kill six others, making her the most prolific killer of children in modern British history.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The Women and Children’s Building at the Countess of Chester Hospital in Chester, England. Lucy Letby was convicted of murdering seven babies and attempting to murder six more in the neonatal ward.

item.title: Caroline Kennedy Visits Solomon Islands Where J.F.K. Survived an Ordeal
item.description: Ms. Kennedy’s recent swim in the Pacific waters where J.F.K. survived a wartime ordeal shows how her family legacy informs her work.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caroline Kennedy paddling with two local women between Olasana Island and Kennedy Island during a visit to the Solomon Islands this month.

item.title: Mountain Chairlift’s Cables Break, Leaving Children Dangling for Hours
item.description: A rescue operation was being mobilized in Pakistan after the cable car malfunctioned while ferrying students to school at an altitude of more than 6,000 feet.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: A soldier descended from a helicopter during a mission to rescue students stuck in a cable car in the mountainous Khyber-Pakhthunkwa Province of Pakistan on Tuesday.

item.title: Sunflower Farm Warns Guests, ‘Keep Your Clothes On’
item.description: A summer getaway southwest of London put up signs asking people to stop posing for risqué photos where other guests, including children, could see.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Ukrainian Drones Are Intercepted Over Russia, Including Near Moscow
item.description: Russia said it intercepted drones in two parts of the country, in what appeared to be the latest in a string of Ukrainian attacks designed to bring the war home to Russia’s citizens.
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:description: The site of a reported drone attack in Krasnogorsk, a town near Moscow, on Tuesday.

item.title: Taliban Members Are Accused of Targeting Afghan Ex-Officials
item.description: A U.N. mission in Afghanistan reported summary killings, arbitrary detentions and torture of hundreds of onetime soldiers, police officers and others in the old government.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Taliban security patrol in Kandahar, Afghanistan, on the second anniversary of the militants’ takeover.

item.title: Zimbabwe Voters to Elect President While Trained Workers Flee
item.description: Nurses, doctors and workers of all kinds are seeking to escape the country’s economic turmoil, an issue that has become a central theme in the election scheduled for Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Tendai Marima and John Eligon
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition leader Nelson Chamisa during a campaign event in Harare, Zimbabwe’s capital, on Monday. Mr. Chamisa lost out to Emmerson Mnangagwa, the current president, in the 2018 election.

item.title: At Risk of Invasion or Lovely to Visit: Two Views of a Polish Border Area
item.description: Polish authorities have issued dire warnings that the Suwalki Gap, on Poland’s northern border between Russia and Belarus, is under threat. Locals say that is just election-related fear-mongering.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Kasia Strek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town center of Suwalki, Poland, this month. Local residents say that the government’s warnings that Russian mercenaries pose a threat to the region are false.

item.title: Thai Ex-Prime Minister Returns From Exile Amid Growing Political Chaos
item.description: Thaksin Shinawatra was ousted in a coup in 2006. He arrived in Thailand as the country struggles to elect a new leader, and was quickly taken to prison.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Thaksin Shinawatra, the former prime minister of Thailand, returned home on Tuesday following 15 years of self-imposed exile.

item.title: Cambodia Leader, Hun Sen, Appoints Hun Manet as New Prime Minister
item.description: Gen. Hun Manet is expected to guide a generational shift in Cambodian politics, taking over for his father Hun Sen, one of the world’s longest-ruling prime ministers.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Tang Chhin Sothy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Hun Manet, center, arriving at the National Assembly in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Tuesday to be elected as the country’s new prime minister.

item.title: Japan to Release Treated Water From Fukushima Nuclear Plant
item.description: In the face of regional and domestic objections, the country plans to proceed with a discharge at Fukushima that will eventually reach more than a million tons of water.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masatsugu Shibata, a fisherman near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, is concerned the plan to release the water will threaten his livelihood.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Japan’s Radioactive Water
item.description: Also, Ukrainian soldiers playing video games.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in 2019.

item.title: Could U.S. Toughness on Chinese Business Have Unintended Consequences?
item.description: Businesses fear that efforts to look tough on Beijing, which have the potential to be more expansive than moves by the federal government, could have unintended consequences.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Lewis Ableidinger for The New York Times

item.title: Nuclear War Could End the World, but What if It’s All in Our Heads?
item.description: Some experts want to apply recent neuroscience research to the decision making that could lead to doomsday.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 1973: 35 Israeli Settlements Planned in Arab Area
item.description: Israel announced further plans to build in territories captured in the 1967 war.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Zelensky Thanks Denmark for Pledging to Donate F-16 Fighter Jets
item.description: The Netherlands and Denmark became the first countries to announce that they would donate the planes.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, and Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark sitting in an F-16 fighter jet at an air base in Vojens, Denmark, on Sunday.

item.title: Flight Risk
item.description: We’re covering near misses on airport runways, severe weather and the Women’s World Cup.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: LaGuardia Airport.

item.title: Radioactive Water Is Complicating Japan and Korea’s New Friendship
item.description: Japan’s plan to discharge treated water from its destroyed Fukushima nuclear plant has triggered a backlash in the region, especially in highly polarized South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daiichi Power Plant in 2019.

item.title: Ukraine is building a case of ecocide against Russia as dolphins keep dying in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

item.title: There is a crisis of wounded psyches among Ukrainian soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung

item.title: Ecuador Election: Leftist González and Newcomer Noboa Move to Runoff
item.description: Luisa González and Daniel Noboa were the top candidates to emerge from Sunday’s election in a country where declining security has been the leading issue for most voters.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky, José María León Cabrera and Thalíe Ponce
item.media:description: Luisa González, left, and Daniel Noboa will compete in a runoff election on Oct. 15.

item.title: Arévalo Wins Election in Guatemala
item.description: The landslide victory by the candidate of an upstart party signals an uncertain new chapter in Central America’s largest country.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jody García
item.media:description: Bernardo Arévalo, right, celebrating with his running mate, Karin Herrera, in Guatemala City on Sunday.

item.title: A Kiss After Spain’s World Cup Win Prompts Many to Cry Foul
item.description: A soccer federation chief kissed the Spanish forward Jennifer Hermoso fully on the lips during the medals ceremony, an unpleasant reminder to many of the sexism that has plagued women’s soccer.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Jennifer Hermoso, center, and her teammates on Sunday in Sydney, Australia, celebrating Spain’s first Women’s World Cup victory.

item.title: Monday Briefing: A Tricky Opportunity in Indonesia
item.description: Also, the nostalgic craft of miniatures in China.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nickel mining site in North Konawe in Sulawesi, Indonesia.

item.title: Spanish Fans Rejoice at World Cup Win
item.description: The final against England brought out fans of all stripes and rallied girls in both countries to hit the field and play.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Soccer fans gathered in the Spanish city of Gijón on Sunday to watch the Women’s World Cup final between England and Spain.

item.title: Ukrainian Commanders Confident About Offensive Despite Problems
item.description: Despite tough fighting and heavy casualties, Ukrainian commanders say their forces are in better shape now than just months ago, while Russian troops appear worse off.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: The Ukrainian 80th Air Assault Brigade prepared for an evening assault against Russian forces near Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, on Aug. 14.

item.title: Guatemala’s Election: What to Know About the Candidates, Issues and Results
item.description: A former first lady and an anticorruption candidate are on the ballot in a runoff contest.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jody García
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guatemalans will head to the polls for a runoff presidential election on Sunday, pitting Sandra Torres against Bernardo Arévalo.

item.title: Ukraine Will Get F-16 Fighter Jets From Denmark and Netherlands
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said the Netherlands had agreed to supply 42 of the jets. Denmark also said it would donate the planes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Vivek Shankar
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at an air base in the Netherlands yesterday.

item.title: Ecuador’s Election: What to Know
item.description: With the country’s attention riveted on violence perpetrated by gangs and drug cartels, the security issue is paramount — and may be decisive.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and José María León Cabrera
item.media:credit: Johanna Alarcon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of a presidential candidate, Yaku Pérez, during a campaign rally this month in Quito, the capital.

item.title: Wildfire in Kelowna, British Columbia, Expected to Leave Lasting Scar
item.description: Fire is raging in the suburban fringes of the resort town of Kelowna, British Columbia, as a state of emergency across the province continued.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The McDougall Creek fire approached houses in West Kelowna, British Columbia, on Friday. Thousands of residents have been forced to evacuate the area due to the fire, one of several burning in the west and north of Canada.

item.title: Mexico Braces for Rain and Flooding from Hurricane Hilary
item.description: The torrential rain and flooding that threaten Southern California also menaced Baja California, the western Mexico peninsula that is popular with tourists.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Elda Cantú and Aline Corpus
item.media:description: Strong winds caused by Hurricane Hilary were already whipping La Paz, in the Mexican state of Baja California Sur. The storm is expected to make landfall early Sunday.

item.title: Egypt’s President Pardons an Arab Spring Activist After Nearly 10 Years in Prison
item.description: Ahmed Douma was one of the best-known faces of Egypt’s 2011 uprising. Rights groups say thousands of political prisoners remain detained under President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ahmed Douma listening to the verdict in court during his 2015 trial in Cairo.

item.title: Jean-Louis Georgelin, Who Was in Charge of Rebuilding Notre-Dame, Dies
item.description: A former army chief of staff, he was put in charge of the cathedral’s restoration and prided himself on keeping the project on track.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Jean-Louis Georgelin, the army general who had been leading the restoration of Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris, in 2021.

item.title: Deadly Russian Strike Hits Chernihiv, Ukraine Says
item.description: The attack, which killed at least seven people and wounded more than 100, came after President Vladimir V. Putin visited a Russian city that was briefly seized by the Wagner group.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A theater after it was damaged by a Russian attack in Chernihiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: U.S.-Japan-South Korea Security Pact Likely to Deepen China’s Dismay
item.description: What its signers, Japan, South Korea and the United States, call deterrence, China characterizes as encirclement, even provocation.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Olivia Wang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea, left, and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan at Camp David on Friday.

item.title: Brazil Found the Last Survivors of an Amazon Tribe. Now What?
item.description: Pakyi and Tamandua are the final known isolated members of the Piripkura people. They are posing a tricky challenge for Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Manuela Andreoni

item.title: How European Officials View a Possible Second Trump Term
item.description: The prospect of a second presidential term for Donald J. Trump has many officials worried about alliance cohesion, NATO and the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump in Erie, Pa., in July. Discussions among European leaders of the possibility of his returning to the White House are intensifying.

item.title: A Ceaseless War Leaves Lethal Threats Lurking Underfoot
item.description: Even as the fighting in Syria has largely stalled, more than a decade of conflict has left behind an array of unexploded munitions like cluster bombs. An earthquake in February heightened the risks.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Nicole Tung
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two year old Noorhan Latqani was severely injured, along with two others including another young girl, when an unknown munition exploded after residents of their local village set a fire to burn trash, seen here in a hospital in Binnish, Syria.

item.title: In France, ‘Climate Fresk’ Global Warming Workshops Are a Hit
item.description: More than a million people in France have attended a “Climate Fresk” class to understand the process of global warming. The project is now spreading abroad.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Participants in a “Climate Fresk,” a workshop that teaches the fundamentals of global warming. Groups use cards to recreate the chain of climate change and debate possible solutions.

item.title: In China, Artists Create Miniature Homes From Memories
item.description: China’s rapid economic growth has meant the demolition of countless rural homes, and a burgeoning nostalgia. That’s where the miniaturists come in.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Qilai Shen
item.media:description: A miniature home is prepared in the studio of Li Yizhong, a Chinese artist who once created large-scale sculptures for office buildings and is now one of China’s most popular miniaturists.

item.title: Women’s World Cup Final Reminds England of Men’s Team’s Painful History
item.description: The women play Spain on Sunday, hoping to end a nearly six-decade national wait for a World Cup win — a reminder of the travails of the Three Lions, the country’s long-suffering men’s team.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: England’s players in a huddle before the second half of the team’s quarterfinal against Colombia last Saturday.

item.title: China to Stage Military Exercises Around Taiwan
item.description: The joint air and sea drills, widely expected in response to a presidential candidate’s visit to the United States, so far appear to be relatively limited.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Chinese military helicopters flying off the coast of Fujian Province in China, near Taiwan, last year.

item.title: U.S. Seals Security Pact With Japan and South Korea as Threats Loom
item.description: While the former president’s name appeared nowhere in the communique issued by three leaders, one of the subtexts was the possibility that he could return to power in next year’s election and disrupt ties with America’s two closest allies in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea, left, and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan at Camp David on Friday.

item.title: Judge Throws Out Confession of Bombing Suspect as Derived From Torture
item.description: The Saudi defendant, accused of orchestrating the attack on the U.S.S. Cole in 2000, was waterboarded and subjected to other forms of torture by the C.I.A. in 2002 in a secret prison network.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri is accused of orchestrating Al Qaeda’s suicide bombing of the U.S. warship Cole on Oct. 12, 2000, in the harbor of Aden, Yemen, that killed 17 U.S. sailors.

item.title: Junta Official in Niger Claims Captive President Will Not Be Harmed
item.description: In an interview with The New York Times, a civilian leader of the junta sounded a conciliatory tone. He also said Niger would not summon the Kremlin-backed Wagner mercenary group.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Ali Lamine Zeine, named prime minister of Niger by coup leaders who seized power last month, is a former finance minister. He is seen here at the International Monetary Fund in Washington, in 2008.

item.title: Canada Wildfires Force Evacuations in Yellowknife and Kelowna
item.description: The emergency order was issued late Friday as wildfires threatened Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories, and Kelowna, in British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A satellite image showing wildfires burning near Yellowknife, the capital of the Northwest Territories, on Wednesday.

item.title: Guatemala’s Anti Corruption Crusader is on Cusp of Presidency
item.description: Can an intellectual on an anti-graft crusade win the presidency in a nation sliding toward authoritarianism? Guatemala is about to find out.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jody García
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bernardo Arévalo at his home this month in Guatemala City. Polls suggest he will win Sunday’s presidential election.

item.title: Ukraine War Casualties Near Half a Million, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Ukraine and Russia have lost a staggering number of troops as Kyiv’s counteroffensive drags on. A lack of rapid medical care has added to the toll.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. officials said Ukraine had suffered close to 70,000 killed and 100,000 to 120,000 wounded.

item.title: Tenerife Wildfire Forces Thousands to Evacuate
item.description: The blaze on Tenerife has burned almost 10,000 acres and forced thousands of residents in the north to lock down or flee.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A firefighter in Arafo on the Canary Island of Tenerife on Wednesday.

item.title: Intelligence Agencies Warn Foreign Spies Are Targeting U.S. Space Companies
item.description: U.S. officials say Chinese and Russian spy agencies are trying to steal technology from private American space companies and preparing cyberattacks that could disable satellites in a conflict.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A broad warning from the federal government said that foreign intelligence services could be targeting space firms, their employees and the contractors that serve those companies.
